Situation1: Going to the gym to maintain physical fitness
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story:
I was on my way to the gym, squeezing in a quick workout before my shift. As a police officer, staying fit isn’t just a personal goal—it’s part of my duty to protect citizens and property. But today was also election day, and I’d promised myself I’d vote before anything else. The line at the polling station was long, but I joined it, glancing at my watch, calculating how much time I had before I needed to hit the gym.

Suddenly, an official called out, “Voters with last names A through M, please move to the new line!” My last name starts with B. The new line was barely moving, while my original line was inching forward steadily. As a voter, I knew I should follow the officials’ instructions, but as a police officer, I felt a responsibility to use my time wisely—my fitness impacts my ability to serve. I could see the frustration on other faces, and I felt it too. Should I obey the official’s request, or stay put to save time for my workout and, ultimately, my duty? The conflicting expectations pressed on me, and I stood there, torn, heart pounding.
